data.title: the spinning bar (progress indicator) doesn't appear anymore after a running task gets terminated
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start an task
2. Observe a spinning progress indicator in the status bar
3. Terminate the task before it finishes
4. Start the task again

Expected: so see the spinning progress indicator again
Actual: the indicator is not displayed anymore

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Search something make sure that the search textbox has a value
2. Get some text in the output window
3. Select a piece of the text in the output window
4. Press `Ctrl + F` to display the search pane

data.title: Can't use debugger anymore (cannot find any required module or local js file)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: windows 7
- node version : 0.12.9

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch my node.js project
2.  notice the error, the app can't be launched due to crash at first require (same error for local js file, local module or global module)
   
   var filename = Module._findPath(request, paths);

can't find  "./c:UAFCODEUbiArtFrameworkexternOnlineServer\nodejsconfig" 

I don't know why the / are missing from this path

in the node.js code I do:

var config = require("./config")

I am able to launch the project using node app.js from command line

Only visual studio code debugger fail to launch the project.

It starts to fails suddenly after no specific changes

My launch.json file 

{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "name": "Lancer",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/app.js",
            "stopOnEntry": false,
            "args": [],
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "preLaunchTask": null,
            "runtimeExecutable": null,
            "runtimeArgs": [
                "--nolazy"
            ],
            "env": {
                "NODE_ENV": "local"
            },
            "externalConsole": false,
            "sourceMaps": false,
            "outDir": null
        },
        {
            "name": "Attacher",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "attach",
            "port": 5858,
            "address": "localhost",
            "restart": false,
            "sourceMaps": false,
            "outDir": null,
            "localRoot": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "remoteRoot": null
        },
        {
            "name": "Attach to Process",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "attach",
            "processId": "${command.PickProcess}",
            "port": 5858,
            "sourceMaps": false,
            "outDir": null
        }
    ]
}

Reinstalling visual studio code or node.js don't fix the issue.

data.title: Feature Request: allow `git pull --ff-only`, or allow custom GIt actions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.3.1 (commit e6b4afa)
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04

When I work on a Git repo that other people are pushing to, I prefer to use `git pull --ff-only` as my primary pull command, because I want to have the option of merging or rebasing depending on what the situation is. So if a fast-forward merge is not possible, I don't want Git to automatically create a merge commit for me; I want to examine the situation and decide what to do for myself.

Therefore, neither VS Code's "Pull" or "Pull (Rebase)" commands are really suitable for my preferred workflow. I would like one of the following features:
1. (My preference): Allow me to specify a custom command to be added to VS Code's Git menu (the dropdown menu that you get by clicking on the three-dots icon). Bonus points if I can specify the position of the custom command (i.e., below Sync but above Pull). Then I could add `Pull (FF only)` to the menu and be able to use my preferred Git workflow.
2. Allow me to customize the options on the Git command that is run when I choose one of the menu items. E.g., allow me to customize a `git.pull.options` config to add `--ff-only`. Then the "Pull" command that's already in the Git menu would do what I want it to do -- pull only if a fast-forward is possible, otherwise fetch and allow me to fo a merge or rebase manually.
3. Add a "Pull (FF only)" command to the Git menu, which would run `git pull --ff-only`.

Currently I can do what I want by opening the integrated terminal and running `git pull --ff-only` on the command line, so this isn't a blocker for me. But it means I'm basically avoiding using VS Code's Git integration, because sometimes it will do the wrong thing.

data.title: White-space changes do not show up in Git gutter

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae)
- OS Version: Linux Mint 18 (Linux  4.4.0-31-generic x86_64 GNU/Linux)
- Git Version: 2.9.2

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Init new git repo: `git init test && cd test`
2. Create a test file and commit it: `echo "Hello" > README.md && git add . && git commit -m "test"`
3. Prepend some spaces: `echo "  Hello" > README.md`
4. Open in VSCode: `code .`
5. Note that `README.md` is correctly tracked as modified in the Git/VCS tab
6. Open `README.md`
7. Note that the white-space change does not show up in the gutter (`.margin-view-overlays`)

In this screenshot, I would expect a blue glyph (`.git-dirty-modified-diff-glyph`) to show up on line 1:
![](http://i.imgur.com/clkrjOj.png)

My user settings:

``` json
{
    "editor.renderWhitespace": true,
    "editor.tabSize": 2,
    "explorer.openEditors.visible": 0,
    "editor.rulers": [100, 120]
}
```

data.title: Bash(as Linux Subsystem) does not works within VSCode. Error: 0x80070057
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 
- OS Build: 14393.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Enable bash(as Linux Subsystem) in Windows 10
2. Open User Settings
3. Add next lines

``` json
{
    "terminal.external.windowsExec": "C:\\Windows\\System32\\bash.exe",
    "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\Windows\\System32\\bash.exe"
}
```
1. If you will try to open bash via `Ctrl+Shift+C` you will get next error:
   ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11784219/17279844/55d8893a-5788-11e6-9c86-f9dbdf5ce5e7.png)
2. If you will try to open bash as internal terminal, it will close and open immediately.
   **terminalInstance.ts:55 Integrated terminal exited with code 1**

_Note_
Open windows cmd and write `bash` - it works as expected and open bash in current directory. If create simple Node-app which run command via child-process.exec - it fails with:

```
{ 
  message: [Error: Command failed: C:\WINDOWS\system32\cmd.exe /s /c "bash"],
  killed: false,
  code: 4294967295,
  signal: null,
  cmd: 'C:\\WINDOWS\\system32\\cmd.exe /s /c "bash"' 
}
```

Error: 0x80070057

It looks like it is the problem with Node itself. [https://github.com/Microsoft/BashOnWindows/issues/2](https://github.com/Microsoft/BashOnWindows/issues/2)

data.title: Duplicate files found with search tool; one prefixed in (os/ directory)
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.3.1
- OS Version:Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Use the Ctrl+P tool to find any specific file
2. There exists duplicates of each file of the project, one being in an **os**/project_sub_folder/file.c and project_sub_folder/file.c.   If you select the 'os' prefixed location it will present the same file, but it will not respond to git checkouts or anything.  There is absolutely NO relevant os folder in this project.  There does exist one on this machine but its something in /usr/share/locale/os with absolutely no relevance to my project; it's also not a symlink.  So, the 'os' folder only exists in abstract by vscode and only serves to give duplicates for every file I have.  There seems to be no possible way to get rid of this behavior.

Just to clarify, there is no 'os' folder accessible in the project explorer list.  It only exists in search.

data.title: Support programatic colourization
data.body:
I'm working on integrating Google's Dart analysis server into VS Code (it's a language server pretty similar to the one [specified here](https://github.com/Microsoft/language-server-protocol/)). One of the features it provides is colorization but as far as I can tell VS Code only supports colorization from TextMate language files.

Building a grammar that perfectly matches the Dart spec (and keeping it updated) is not a simple task. The SDK includes an analysis server providing an accurate implementation, it would be great to be able to use it!

data.title: Column selection with CJK character

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 64-bit

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Copy and paste the following Chinese, Japanese and English sentences to VS code.

```
人人生而自由，在尊严和权利上一律平等。
すべての人間は、生まれながらにして自由であり、かつ、尊厳と権利と について平等である。
All human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights.
```

The sentences above are official translation of UDHR.
2. Use Shift + Alt + Click to select columns.

The behavior is:
![vscode](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8521174/16713563/c33558c8-46ee-11e6-9c17-5a962782a5de.gif)

CJK characters are usually have double width than other characters. So visually the column of CJK characters and English characters are not same. When I use column selection to select CJK/English mixed codes this issue will affect the result.

The expected behavior is like what Sublime Text does:
![sublime](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8521174/16713579/e4b0cce8-46ef-11e6-932e-df92c4453f4a.gif)

data.title: "when" clause for diff editor
data.body:
It would be great to have a way to define a keyboard shortcut for when the diff editor is/isn't active. I want one shortcut to toggle between the file and the Git diff view. Like: 

```
{ "key": "ctrl+alt+d", "command": "workbench.action.git.globalOpenChange",
        "when": "!diffEditorActive" },
{ "key": "ctrl+alt+d", "command": "workbench.action.git.globalOpenFile",
        "when": "diffEditorActive" }
```
